Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exploiting Instruction-Based and User-Behavior-Based Prediction for Energy and Performance Management in Operating Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving energy efficiency is critical since future users will demand mobile devices with even longer battery life or higher performance stationary systems that are cost effective to operate even when energy costs increase. The challenge that efficient energy management faces is matching the power state of the system resources to the application or user demand. The goal is to reduce energy consumption by keeping the device in the low-power state when not used, but at the same time provide high response when the demand for the device arrives. Current solutions are either not transparent and require programmer involvement, or are less effective in reducing energy consumption and can expose significant delays to the application and the user. The goal of the proposed work is to design a fully autonomous and unified system that will transparently examine and adapt to application demands of both interactive as well as non-interactive applications in the current and future systems. This goal will be achieved through highly detailed user and application behavior monitoring in the operating system for interactive system, and application monitoring for non-interactive server type systems. Capturing and understanding such user and application behavior is critical in meeting user demand for high performance while saving energy.

The project will involve students in designing and evaluating energy-efficient mechanisms for various system components and device types through in-class assignments as well as independent studies. The projects and assignments will provide students with better understanding of the challenges that they will face in their future careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy is a critical system resource for both portable and stationary systems. The need for energy efficiency in portable systems is clear: batteries have a limited energy capacity and users are expecting not only higher performance but longer battery life with every new system they buy. Energy efficiency in datacenters or cloud computing infrastructure also demands highest considerations as it provides positive financial and environmental benefits. The challenge of designing energy efficient systems lies in understanding the role of user interactions in energy consumption and in providing an energy/performance schedule that accommodates user demand. Subsequently, the goal of this project was understanding user behavior, how it impacts system demand, and how we can optimize system performance by tailoring it to a user’s patterns of interaction.

 

This project resulted in numerous studies being conducted and solutions being proposed to address impact of user behavior and expectation on energy efficiency of the system.  General systems, both portable as well as a servers or desktops, consist of: CPU to execute instructions, memory to store temporary application state, permanent storage, a network interface to allow external communication, and finally, a way of interacting with a system such as a keyboard, mouse, or a touchscreen.  All of those system devices respond to user input and application execution as demanded by the users. The results of this project have shown that all of the system devices have a regular and predictable behavior based on user demands. Memory, storage, CPU, and a network interfaced have different power states based on the demand placed on them. This project leverages the observation of user behavior and interaction with the system to provide a complete set of mechanisms to manage the power states of the system components to minimize energy usage while providing the performance the user demands and expects from the system.

 

The results from this project are expected to lead to a better understanding of the user interactions with the system, the demand placed on the system, and the energy efficient way of meeting user expectations. The developed mechanisms also enable further research in energy efficiency of systems. One example of such adaptation is user behavior based optimization of energy in a fitness monitoring, where the monitoring level depends on user activity allowing for more energy efficient and accurate monitoring. Therefore, this projects provides a fundamental set of mechanisms not only for more classical systems such as servers or smartphones, but also emerging devices such as wearable monitors and sensors (smartwatches, fitness bands, etc.).

 

This research project trained students in building practical and efficient computer systems to support energy conservation while still preserving performance and user expectations. Students trained on developing system optimization in variety of environments from server class systems down to smartwatches, which will enhance their future technical careers. In addition, the PI has introduced a new course in Green Computing. The Green Computing class offers students the opportunity to learn about energy efficiency of systems and the related factors such as impact on performance and usability of devices under energy management.
